Wow that was super quick :) .

[REEF-pull-request-windows3 #132](https://builds.apache.org/job/REEF-pull-request-windows3/132/) SUCCESS
This pull request looks good

@bgchun 

``` java
VortexFuture enqueueMockedTasklet(final Tasklet tasklet)
```

Without this method currently there's no way for us to check the state of `Tasklet`. In current unit tests that test `DefaultVortexMaster`, we pass mocked `Tasklet`s whose ids we know to here and use their ids to track their state.(e.g. whether they were scheduled to a worker).

If we are to remove this method, I think we need to have each `VortexFuture` hold onto its corresponding `Tasklet`'s id. In this way we can use the following same method that the Vortex user api uses and still obtain the `Tasklet`'s id. But I do not prefer this approach because it exposes `Tasklet` ids to Vortex users.

``` java
VortexFuture<TOutput> enqueueTasklet(final VortexFunction<TInput, TOutput> function, final TInput input)
```

Another approach is to change the structure of `DefaultVortexMasterTest` unit test.

Maybe I'm missing something? What are your thoughts?

@johnyangk If you need to change the behavior of `pendingTasklets` for your unit tests, maybe the dependency should be explicit for testing. Having a special method for unit tests indicates code smell.
@bgchun Okay then I'll work on changing the overall code structure such that we can do without the special method.

[Reef-pull-request-ubuntu #218](https://builds.apache.org/job/Reef-pull-request-ubuntu/218/) SUCCESS
This pull request looks good

[Reef-pull-request-ubuntu #219](https://builds.apache.org/job/Reef-pull-request-ubuntu/219/) SUCCESS
This pull request looks good

@bgchun 
Addressed your comments by
- Refactoring out the scheduler thread into a wake stage to be invoked by `VortexDriver`
- Creating injectable `PendingTasklets` to be injected into the scheduler and `DefaultVortexMaster`

By taking out these two dependencies from `DefaultVortexMaster`, the unit tests can now do the scheduling by itself without having to rely on special methods.

FYI: Fastest way to test Vortex
- At the REEF root directory, `mvn clean install -DskipTests`
- At lang\java\reef-applications, `mvn test`
- At lang\java\reef-tests, `mvn -Dtest=AddOneTest test`
I've republished the same change (merged with one more commit from the master) and the test failure didn't repeat; probably was transient.

[REEF-pull-request-windows3 #133](https://builds.apache.org/job/REEF-pull-request-windows3/133/) SUCCESS
This pull request looks good
@johnyangk Thanks. Looks good. I will test it and merge it if everything goes well.

@bgchun 
Sorry, I just pushed a one-line change to fix a bug I just found. Please use that as well. Thank you!
This PR assumes that NCS will be used from a Task. Other services may want to use NCS as well. Does adding a configuration helper for Service/Context make sense at all?

@dafrista Good question! I just supposed that services which use NCS run on top of a task. That said, NCS is a service for communication between tasks. I didn't consider a situation where NCS is used in contexts. This is why current NCS has just one id. 

Maybe, we need to support multiple ids per NCS if we want the NCS is also used in multiple contexts.

We should not assume that the NCS is used only by tasks.

On Tue, Aug 4, 2015 at 3:44 PM, Tae-Geon Um notifications@github.com
wrote:

> 
> —

[Reef-pull-request-ubuntu #220](https://builds.apache.org/job/Reef-pull-request-ubuntu/220/) SUCCESS
This pull request looks good

@dafrista @bgchun Actually, NCS can be used within contexts if the client services use taskId for communication. But, it is not possible to use NCS before task is started. Is this a problem? and Is it reasonable for a NCS to have multiple ids?

[Reef-pull-request-ubuntu #221](https://builds.apache.org/job/Reef-pull-request-ubuntu/221/) SUCCESS
This pull request looks good
@markusweimer  I have taken another pass

@dafrista I've looked at "@Deprecated" code in the current reef codebase. I'm not happy with the status quo. It's hard to figure out when and why a method/constructor's deprecated. `reef-io` needs cleanup.

May I ask you why you did not remove all Wake deprecated methods/constructors in this pull request?
@dafrista Can you explain "TODO: [REEF-547] Removed a variant of a deprecated constructor" better?
@bgchun I started with a subset, because I found that some Wake `@Deprecated` are being used elsewhere in non-deprecated parts of the code. These dependencies are not so easy to untangle.

[Reef-pull-request-ubuntu #222](https://builds.apache.org/job/Reef-pull-request-ubuntu/222/) SUCCESS
This pull request looks good

[Reef-pull-request-ubuntu #223](https://builds.apache.org/job/Reef-pull-request-ubuntu/223/) FAILURE
Looks like there's a problem with this pull request

@bgchun The first two constructors were deprecated since 0.11, so they meet our rules about what can be removed. As far as I can tell, the last constructor

```
public NameServerImpl(
    final int port,    
    final IdentifierFactory factory,   
    final ReefEventStateManager reefEventStateManager,   
    final LocalAddressProvider localAddressProvider)
```

was actually added after 0.11 (https://github.com/apache/incubator-reef/commit/0f632ca864c8356e22981f598d31c89cfd7c4a94), but added with the `@Deprecated` annotation. I felt this is just a 'variant' of the other constructors and should be removed. But it's a judgment call.

@dafrista Thanks. I don't mean that we have to discuss non-deprecated part dependency in this pull request. Deprecation annotations in `reef.io` are confusing. `reef.io` needs some non-trivial clean up.

I'm wondering if it's good to have this partial cleanup before the release. It may be better to have full clean up right after the release.

[REEF-pull-request-windows3 #136](https://builds.apache.org/job/REEF-pull-request-windows3/136/) SUCCESS
This pull request looks good
@bgchun I was hoping to get some cleanup done for this release. My thinking is that the more "straightforward" deprecated parts we remove, the easier discussion should be about the confusing parts.

@dafrista I agree that there are parts that are easy to remove and do not cause any confusion.
But removing some parts made me confused, since the code looked new. :) Also, the comment "+  // TODO: [REEF-547] Removed a variant of a deprecated constructor" was confusing to me. This may be just a problem only I have. :)

@beysims and I have been debugging this offline a bit. The issue seems to be that `Org.Apache.REEF.Client.dll` for me does not, in fact, contain the REEF jar:

```
reef [PR-328]> (Get-Item .\lang\cs\bin\x64\Release\Org.Apache.REEF.Client\Org.Apache.REEF.Client.dll).length
24064
```

Hence, the DLL is ~24kB in size and can't possibly contain the JAR.

What is worrying is that the build actually succeeded.

This seems to be a build order issue. Upon a _second_ build of REEF, I get:

```
reef [PR-328]> (Get-Item .\lang\cs\bin\x64\Release\Org.Apache.REEF.Client\Org.Apache.REEF.Client.dll).length
42776064
```

@beysims Could it be that the dependency of `Org.Apache.REEF.Client` on `Org.Apache.REEF.Bridge.JAR` is not recorded? Also, the first build should have failed because the JAR does not exist, right?

Yes - I've left a comment for `deepCopy()` and fixed other issues.

By the way, what's the etiquette when I fix something you've left a comment about? In Codeflow, for example, I could just mark each individual comment as "resolved" or "closed", but here there seem to be only two technical options - either answer "fixed" to each comment or leave them unanswered and assume that I answer to the ones I don't fix ?
@dkm2110 Done with another pass.

> By the way, what's the etiquette when I fix something you've left a comment about? 

That isn't really well supported in GitHub, sadly. Most people respond inline or leave a comment here on the front page that all issues have been addressed, except where noted. Either way is fine. The former is tricky when also doing rebases, as GitHub then looses the association of the comment with the code.
